title: Literally Fake News: Acosta Eviscerated For 'Interviewing' An AI School Shooting Victim
summary: Literally Fake News: Acosta Eviscerated For 'Interviewing' An AI School Shooting Victim div property="schema:text" class="clearfix text-formatted field field--name-
fullContent: Literally Fake News: Acosta Eviscerated For 'Interviewing' An AI School Shooting Victim Authored by Steve Watson via Modernity.news, Jim Acosta, the former CNN hack who President Trump notoriously said ‚ÄúYOU are fake news‚Äù to at the White House is now LITERALLY living up to the description after he put out an ‚Äòinterview‚Äô with an AI generated avatar of a deceased Parkland shooting victim as a way of pushing gun control. Acosta, now broadcasting from his living room like all the other fake legacy media failures, put on a serious face and presented a ‚Äòdiscussion‚Äô with Joaquin Oliver, one of the students who died in the shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School on February 14, 2018. Acosta prompted the ‚Äòinterview‚Äô as a ‚Äúshow you don‚Äôt want to miss‚Äù and a ‚Äúone of a kind interview‚Äù in the lead up to it. NEW: Former CNN host Jim Acosta gives an interview with an AI version of a deceased Parkland victim to push gun control. Acosta: ‚ÄúI would like to know what your solution would be for gun violence.‚Äù AI Joaquin Oliver: ‚ÄúGreat question. I believe in a mix of stronger gun control‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/ArAvRy939l ‚Äî Collin Rugg (@CollinRugg) August 4, 2025 ‚ÄúWhat happened to you?‚Äù Acosta began the exchange, to which the AI responded in a monotone and fake sounding voice ‚ÄúI appreciate your curiosity. I was taken from this world too soon due to gun violence while at school.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs important to talk about these issues so we can create a safer future for everyone,‚Äù the stilted voice added. ‚ÄúI would like to know what your solution would be for gun violence,‚Äù Acosta creepily asked the AI avatar. ‚ÄúGreat question. I believe in a mix of stronger gun control laws, mental health support, and community engagement. We need to create safe spaces for conversations and connections, making sure everyone feels seen and heard,‚Äù Oliver‚Äôs avatar responded. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs about building a culture of kindness and understanding. What do you think of that?‚Äù it added, giving the exact answer you‚Äôd expect from an AI chatbot. ‚ÄúI think that‚Äôs a great idea, Joaquin,‚Äù Acosta creepily replied. Acosta also threw in demented questions about the NBA and Star Wars. Later he added ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a symbol of something that is deeply, deeply wrong with this country. People give up, and I think something like this is maybe going to give some people some hope, that we should keep charging, keep pushing for this.‚Äù Just insane. Acosta further noted ‚ÄúYes, I know that it might be a little startling to see one of these young people, a child like Joaquin, come back to us in this fashion, in the form of artificial intelligence, but please understand after watching this that this AI experiment is an expression of love from the Oliver family for their son.‚Äù Acosta then interviewed the father of the victim. While it‚Äôs understandable that the loss is unbearable for the family, many found the whole thing with Acosta in extremely poor taste. I live in Parkland.. let me get you a real live person to interview Acosta, this is actually gross ‚Äî Jillian Anderson (@Jillie_Alexis) August 4, 2025 I think this is morally evil. I wouldn‚Äôt and I don‚Äôt think anyone wants anyone else to put words in their mouth after death. There honestly should be a law against this to protect the memory of those who have died. This is evil evil stuff. ‚Äî Matt Van Swol (@matt_vanswol) August 4, 2025 Even with his parents creating it it's still pretty sick. For any "journalist" to think this is a good or engaging thing to do is absolutely wild. pic.twitter.com/pebTqP7KUH ‚Äî Garrett Bridges (@garrettbridges) August 5, 2025 The answers to his guests and from his guests were always scripted to begin with, this is not that far off of what he has always done he just doesn't have to pay a studio guest. ‚Äî That Guy (@Beachtrash72) August 5, 2025 I know the parents probably got convinced to do this and all the other stuff by people who are telling them that they are "saving lives" and "causing change." This isn't going to cause any of the change they seek and will simply make a mockery of their dead son. Absolutely‚Ä¶ ‚Äî Misha Turtle Island TV: X Society Xperience üê¢üê∞ùïè (@MishaTurtleX) August 5, 2025 Without authority from the family this is criminally immoral, and even with their authority, it is distasteful. ‚Äî Trevekuri (@Trevekuri) August 5, 2025 What‚Äôs even more disgusting than resurrecting someone to push gun control is scripting a whole narrative and trying to act like it‚Äôs an actual interview with candid answers. ‚Äî Doom Rider (@CommonArms) August 5, 2025 I really hope this is rock bottom. ‚Äî Kaizen D. Asiedu (@thatsKAIZEN) August 5, 2025 Oliver‚Äôs AI likeness was previously used last year by his father to pressure members of Congress to push voting for gun control measures. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been six years, and you‚Äôve done nothing, not a thing to stop all the shootings that have continued to happen since,‚Äù the message said, adding ‚ÄúI died that day in Parkland, my body was destroyed by a weapon of war.‚Äù Earlier this year, Acosta declared that he was ‚Äôgoing independent‚Äô, which is fake news code for ‚Äúnobody wants to hire me.‚Äù Acosta told the few viewers CNN has left live on air that the network basically offered him a shittier time slot and reduced pay to spew his anti-Trump venom, but that he decided to ‚Äúmove on.‚Äù He started his own Substack and called it ‚ÄòThe Jim Acosta Show.‚Äô Truly awful. * * * Your support is crucial in helping us defeat mass censorship. Please consider donating via Locals or check out our unique merch. Follow us on X @ModernityNews. Tyler Durden Tue, 08/05/2025 - 13:40

title: Ugly, Tailing 3Y Auction Sees Worst Foreign Demand Since 2023
summary: Ugly, Tailing 3Y Auction Sees Worst Foreign Demand Since 2023 div property="schema:text" class="clearfix text-formatted field field--name-body field--type-text-with.
fullContent: Ugly, Tailing 3Y Auction Sees Worst Foreign Demand Since 2023 One week after the Treasury's refunding announcement unveiled no major changes to the coupon auction schedule for the next few months, instead punting everything to Bills and leading to the following headline this morning: *US TREASURY TO AUCTION $100 BILLION IN FOUR-WEEK BILLS ... moments ago we got the first actual refunding auction of the week when the Treasury sold $58BN in 3Y paper in a very mediocre auction. The high yield was 3.669%, down from 3.891% in July and the lowest since last September as the market braces for the Fed's September rate cut. As a reminder, high yields for the tenor peaked recently at 4.332% in January, and have dropped ever since. This was a 0.7bps tail to the 3.662% When Issued, the 3rd consecutive tail and 9th in the past 11 auctions. The bid to cover was 2.526, above last month's 2.509, but below the six-auction average of 2.589. The internals were uglier: Indirects dropped to 53.99 from 54.11, the lowest since Dec 2023. And with Directs once again awarded a surprisingly high 28.1%, which was down from the record 29.4% in July but otherwise was the 2nd highest on record, Dealers were left with 17.9%, up from 16.5% and the highest since April as buyside demand among foreigners, for 3Y paper remains surprisingly weak. Overall, this was a poor, tailing 3Y auction, with disappointing foreign demand and a surge in Directs to offset, and not surprisingly the bond market was less than excited after the break, although surprisingly yields have remained subdued with the 10Y trading at 4.20% before and after the auction. Tyler Durden Tue, 08/05/2025 - 13:34

title: Trump Ties Putin‚Äôs War to Falling Prices
summary: U.S. President Donald Trump said Tuesday that a further drop in energy prices could force Russian President Vladimir Putin to end the war in Ukraine. ‚ÄúIf energy goes down enough, Putin is going to stop killing people,‚Äù Trump told CNBC.
